content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments may be included in income. The "Child Support Enforcement Act" ensures the right to receive child support payments and the obligation to pay child support is not affected. Unpaid child support payments are treated as taxable income under Section 108 of the Internal Revenue Code. The term 'taxable unpaid child support payments' refers to payments that the taxpayer was required to pay under a support instrument for the support of their child, meeting specific notice requirements. The eligible taxpayer must send a notice to the individual who failed to make child support payments, including the amount owed and a notification of non-payment. The eligible taxpayer must send a notice to the individual who failed to make child support payments, including the amount owed and a notification of non-payment. If the address is unknown, the Secretary will send the notice if the address is available. If the address is unknown, no income shall be included in gross income for any taxable year before the calendar year preceding the year in which notice can be sent. Subsequent payments required to be included in gross income will be allowed if made. The amendments made by this section allow subsequent payments required to be included in gross income to be deducted in the taxable year they are made. Definitions for 'applicable child support payments' and 'eligible taxpayer' are provided in section 166(f). Effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 4. ALLOWANCE OF BAD DEBT DEDUCTION FOR UNPAID CHILD SUPPORT PAYMENTS. Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow a deduction for unpaid child support payments for eligible taxpayers. Subsections (a) and (d) do not apply to these payments, and the taxpayer can deduct the amount of unpaid child support payments remaining at the end of the taxable year. The amended Section 166 of the Internal Revenue Code allows eligible taxpayers to deduct unpaid child support payments. The deduction is limited to $10,000 per child for individuals with an adjusted gross income not exceeding $50,000. The term 'eligible taxpayer' refers to an individual whose adjusted gross income is under $50,000, with unpaid child support payments of $500 or more, and who meets identification requirements. The term 'applicable child support payment' pertains to the eligible taxpayer's unpaid child support for a taxable year. The term 'applicable child support payment' refers to required payments for the support of a qualifying child by an individual under a support instrument meeting specific requirements during a taxable year. The term 'qualifying child' in this context refers to a child of an eligible individual for whom a deduction is allowable under specific tax code sections. The payments must be delinquent for at least a full year. Payments must be delinquent for at least a full year to not be treated as an applicable unpaid child support payment. In the 1st taxable year, payments from any individual shall be considered on a 24-month basis instead of 12 months. The term 'applicable child support payment' excludes amounts assigned to a State under section 408(a)(3) of the Social Security Act. Identification requirements for eligible taxpayers must be met. The identification requirements for eligible taxpayers claiming a deduction under this subsection include providing the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of each child for whom child support payments are required, as well as the individual obligated to make the payments. Failure to provide this information may result in the deduction not being applicable. The identification requirements for eligible taxpayers claiming a deduction under this subsection include providing the name, address, and taxpayer identification number of each child for whom child support payments are required. Failure to provide this information may result in the deduction not being applicable. Cost-of-living adjustments apply for taxable years after 2000 to increase certain dollar amounts specified in the tax code. The deduction amount for eligible taxpayers is adjusted annually based on the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. Any subsequent payments made after the deduction was allowed must be included in the taxpayer's gross income for that year. The support instrument for eligible taxpayers includes a decree of divorce, written separation agreement, or other written instruments incident to divorce. The deduction for unpaid child support payments is allowed for eligible taxpayers through a decree of divorce, written separation agreement, or court order requiring support payments for children. This amendment adds a new paragraph to the tax code for nonitemizers to claim this deduction. The amendment allows for the deduction of unpaid child support payments under section 166(f) of the tax code. Additionally, a new subparagraph (C) is added to section 166(d)(2) for applicable child support payments. These amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. SEC. 5. REDUCTION OF FEDERAL DEBT. Net revenues from this Act will solely retire US public debt, not for other purposes, as per appropriation Acts.
